												Forza 5 is the racer I really want to play but this game is scratching that itch for me at the moment on PC. The handling is very sensitive and each car takes some getting used to but is eventually very satisfying to drive. A good range of difficulty settings and driver assists which you can switch off means you can give yourself a fair challenge and feel satisfied when you drive well. The helmet camera and head physics were my favourite feature from the first Shift game and they return in Shift 2 to make the sensation of racing at speed only just in control of your car, really engaging. Unfortunately the immersion for me goes no further as there is no support for the Microsoft Xbox 360 Wireless Racing Wheel which is my wheel of choice on PC, although in fairness plenty of Logitech wheels are supported. This limitation plus the distinctly floaty nature of the cars' handling causes me to play this game as more of an arcade racer than I do a game like Forza 4, but it is still enjoyable when played with the right expectation. The trusty 360 gamepad is supported and works very well for racing as you would expect. The menus are mostly easy to navigate with the 360 pad but all the on-screen button prompts are for the keyboard. It took me a while to work out how to save settings with the controller (press start) but after some trial and error I can deal with the menus well enough.Shift 2 has a wide selection of real cars and tracks plus a smattering of fictional courses, some of which return from the first game. Full car customisation is provided allowing you to upgrade the performance and customise the appearance of the vehicles quite dramatically. Cars are given an overall performance rating and using this are separated into categories A, B, C, D just as in the original Shift game and familiar to players of other racing sims such as Forza Motosport.The game looks pretty good in 1080p and on my machine (i5, 7850, 8GB RAM) with all presets set to High runs at 50-70 frames per second on the whole, though on certain corners of certain tracks framerate drops into the high 30s. I would like to tweak my settings a bit more to achieve a minimum of 60 but the game offers no benchmark mode so checking the effect of a graphics setting takes a long time - many changes even require you to restart the game. It is also disappointing that the low resolution cutscenes were clearly pre-rendered with consoles in mind which makes the unskippable cinematics during the career mode look very out-dated - cinematics should be used to flatter a game, but in the case of Shift 2 it's a relief to get past them and into the game which itself looks very attractive.The Autolog and Online play require an EA Origin account (though the game does not require the Origin client). Unlike some players on the community hub I had no trouble at all activating the game or fighting with any DRM. The game installed and played easily from Steam just like any other game. Steam Overlay popped up showing me the product key when I first launched the game but I dismissed that as I have never had to type it in yet. I have tried to get an online match on two occassions and both times I was the only player online and had to create a lobby. Hopefully the sale weekend will get some new players lobbying up but I would not recommend this title if you are looking for multiplayer racing. It does provide a satisfying single player experience for players who enjoy racing against AI and testing themselves on simulations of the best cars and circuits in motorsport.To my mind this game was a good buy at the recent sale price of £4.99 but I would hesitate to recommend it at the current full price of £19.99. It is true there are not a lot of other games of this type available on the PC which have the same degree of polish as Shift 2 Unleashed, but there are definitely better experiences out there on Steam for your hard-earned £20.

												I played this game using the unofficial community patch by nogripracing, so I have no experience with the Vanilla version. Also I didn't delve deep into the tuning options and online.As of this writing I clocked in around 37 hours and I am confident to say I really love this game. I played through the first SHIFT and it was my first ever racing game that made the cockpit view comfortable to play with. SHIFT 2 refined the experience with their new Helmet Cam -- The camera is attached to the driver's helmet and it mimics the head movement and shakiness when driving, gives you tunnel vision, and it blurs your vision when you hit a wall. A lot of people say the camera is disorienting, but personally I don't really think so. I was not once disorientated, confused or the effects got in the way of the gameplay. SHIFT 2 is arguably the only racing game that lets you truly be the driver, rather than be the car itself. You feel how scary speed is when driving at 200 miles per hour, underestimate the car, and the car will severely punish you. This what made this game so great for me.Now for the negatives. The menu system is stylish, but atrocious. The key assignments for the buttons are all over the place. I am playing using the 360 controller and the game can't reassign the button icons to match the controller's.Earning money is way too easy. Want to buy that certain car? Grind in Quick Race once your driver level is high. Select the Dakota Oval track, set it to one lap and no opponents, and bam, $20,000 per 35 seconds.Visual customization is basic and practically useless.The slightest bump and the slightest touch to the dirt will send your car spinning. To be fair, I haven't rammed a car or drove off-road in real life before, but these annoyances can ruin the entire race because the AI suddenly bumped into you or you get sucked to the dirt like a black hole.Some of the DLCs are way too easy and one DLC broke the game's pace. The Speedhunter pack gives you the drag racing career, quarter mile career and access to some highly tuned cars. The problem is the cars are free to acquire. I won the drag race and quarter mile career without breaking a sweat because I had free access to the stupidly fast Nissan GT-R. Some of these cars can be used to your default career and I breezed past some of the events.My narrator-guy-person-thing is annoying. I loved the British guy in SHIFT 1 and while the new guy is alright, he's too, uh... Not... I dunno. He's not British-ey and kawaii enough.I hate drifting. I hate drifting in SHIFT 1, and I hate drifting in SHIFT 2.The title of the game is stupid. Really? SHIFT 2 Unleashed? What's next? SHIFT 3 Insurrection? SHIFT 4 Reloaded?Overall I love this game. The negatives are there and noticeable, but the core gameplay, the cars, the races, the tracks, the sights and sounds, are all great.

												I've played NFS: HS (Road Challenge), PU (P 2000), HP 2, MW '05, MW '10 and this - a true NFS fan, that is.Pros:- Physics, realistic loss of traction at high speeds (aye, I've also driven a real car at high speed and lost traction, so I would know).- Lots of interesting game modes.- Lots of interesting tracks, specifically I like how this game doesn't do cheap stuff like track mirroring or obnoxious night time ice skating to bump up difficulty. I also like how some tracks have several variants with common bits.- No catch-up! You actually get what you deserve as far as I can tell. Difficulty is dynamically adjusted in the beginning of each race according to your performance but never mid-race as it used to be.- Graphics are stunning, camera options are good and make a lot of sense (e.g. two different in-cockpit cams with different settings).- Background graphics because no flux were given :D- Lots of settings for the car*- No DLC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, existing cars are all good enough to beat the events, your friends and even clock some serious records.Cons:- Loads of CTDs and sound bugs. For me the source of CTD persists over the CTD, e.g. if I was playing track A with settings XYZ and it crashes, it's gonna crash with track A and XYZ no matter how many times I restart the game. Then again, it fixes itself if I play A with settings XCV or if I play track B.- ...loooong intro videos, yet to look into disabling them. This would be tolerable if for not so many CTDs.- General handling settings. I play with KB and like many people have mentioned, there's a lot of input lag. This, however, is not a true con, because you can always disable the "stabilising" setting:=> Edit DampeningEnabled="1" string to "0" in vehicleset_pc_custom_[controller name here].xmlAlso the default settings for tuning are very very loose and unresponsive at times, do not forget to edit.- While settings are plenty (see pros), the poor default settings force you to make your own. There are a lot of settings there and the explanations for each setting are decent at best - a bit of a learning curve to get them right and you'll need to tap into actual tuning guides for real world cars to get the most out of your ride.- Lamborghini Murcielago LP640 is a Limited Edition only car by default. There are guides to unlock LE cars and events, though, but it's a bit of a nuisance and you'll need to edit the master .exe to achieve this.TL;DR: To get everything out of this game lots of fiddling with game files, game settings and car settings is involved. For this reason I'm going to give 9/10. Otherwise a brilliant, brilliant game.EDIT: This edit is two years after the original review.Changes from my perspective:- The game no longer CTDs...that often. I have reinstalled the game on the same platform but new install of Windows 7, so not much should have changed.- Bought a racing wheel, yay!A wheel definitely helps with some of the rear-wheel drives since it's easier to control the amount of turning than it is with a keyboard. Especially the McLaren F1 and BMW M1 became really pleasant to drive.Settings are still plenty and wide, most of the suspension settings and angles I've learnt to work with but the exact nature of some settings is a mystery to me. I understand them from a literate background but sometimes the car isn't terribly responsive.For most parts I still do agree with my review, though, so if the game is on sale it's a good buy. It's still the best simulator from the NFS series, for whatever that counts.

												Need for Speed all who grew up with that franchise know what that means. Fast cars, nice roads/tracks and lots and lots of action. Even the cops need a rest and so the Shift2 train leaves for arcade and simulation city...  but is it a real simulation then? Back in the day and compared to Race07, GTR2 and other real racing sims of that time Shift2 is no hardcore sim neither is it today.    Compared to Project CARS, Shift2 is more arcade sim racer than hardcore sim. So if you want a real racing sim you better switch to Assetto Corsa or Project CARS. For me Shift is a very good game if you can get used to the sim/arcade controls with that touch of simulation We have  static weather (mid-day, dusk and night) and for today´s standard kinda rusty graphics. Driving through the night however is still impressive as your and your opponents headlights the only light source on the track so when you drive in the middle field you can see nice lighting effects on the cars infront of you and see the packs headlights in the rearview mirror. The sound is superb imho.  The ricer Turbo sounds amazing when it kicks in, exhaust backfire sounds are awesome! For car lovers yeah that´s the kinda sound we wanna hear. The Career mode has lots of different races which will be unlocked when you level up your driver level. The higher your driver level the more upgrades, vinyls and stuff will be available to turn your standard car in a roaring racing car. AI  behavior seems legit to me but you have to upgrade your car otherwise you´re not leading the pack! Shift2 also includes official GT3 and GT1 races which were the reason I bought it. These races will put all your skills to the test. Multiplayer is still available but you should have friends around to fill the mostly empty lobby. If you like racing games this is definitely worth a buy.

												I'd like to give this a sideways thumb because it's honestly a great game, one of the closest games to Forza or Gran Turismo you'll get on PC but it's plagued with technical issues thanks to the passing of time. Some such issues are related to Autolog, which I believe has been long since abandoned which now crashes the game for players, such as myself and requires players to either block certain ports through their firewall or to turn off their internet - just to prevent these problems from happening. Other issues also include the three installs and you're dead situation, where you can only activate the game three times before the key going away, although you can unactivate it, most people either won't remember or won't get the chance ie if their computer dies. Absolutely hate 3rd-party DRMs, developers need to stop and take CD Projekt Red's practices into consideration.Moving away from technical problems.The game is brilliant. The amount and quality of content in this game is superb. This game has a massive selection of variety when it comes to cars and tracks. 160 cars is a lot for a racing game and sure you can compare it to games such as Forza 4 at 600 or Gran Turismo (I don't actually know the amount for GT6, I remember GT5 being around 1200) but it doesn't really matter. The car choice in this game focuses on cars that matter in their perspective, which is generally the well known cars such as the Corvette ZR1, Lamborghini Gallardo or Porsche 911 GT3. It doesn't really have any "trash" filler cars as such, apart from the Legends DLC, free on PC, which introduced things like the Mini and the Alfa Romeo Giulia Sprint GTA, which I don't mind, most of the cars are an enthralling experience to drive due to excellent sound design and well made cockpits. There's a view mode that allows the player to not just drive in first person but there's a helmet overlay that feels realistic and the camera moves when approaching a corner. Dials and screens inside cars all light up and work, like the Caterham has a working, although I wouldn't say incredibly realistic Water Temperature monitor which adds to the immersion. Not just this, but full car customization is also put into play. You have full control over tuning and modifying parts for your car. Want to engine swap a Nissan Silvia S15 and take out the SR20DET with a Skyline engine. Sure. It's freedom over car design is a definite plus.Gameplay consists of a mainly realistic racing experience, not the simulator experience of Assetto Corsa, which puts me off a little bit nor the overly arcade experiences found in your other modern Need for Speed titles since Undercover. It's always intense and if you're like me and turn off every assist, turn up the difficulty, you'll be in for an extraordinary time. Graphically it's top of the line, 2011 graphics. Yes I'm saying this looks (on MAX settings, which mind you, on my R9 280X only reaches 45-50 FPS on some tracks, strangely) better than most of the games that came out in 2011. The reflections, bloom FX, which I find disorientating at times, textures, etc are just really good. Campaign is good. Not much to say, it's sort of like an RPG, you level up and with that you get cash, liveries and rims. You do different events for XP and cash, that's pretty much it. And then you can challenge famous drivers and take their highly modified cars. And finally Tracks. There's a lot of Tracks and variations in NFS Shift 2. Renowned tracks like Silverstone, Brands Hatch, Suzuka Circuit and many others feature in Shift 2 with night variations and different weather variations. Brilliant. Different terrains on different tracks heavily impact your car and it's traction. If you manage to drift offroad and into sand, you're done for. Nothing is holding you back from doing a barrel roll right into the wall. And this has happened to me, most notably in the lighter cars I drive, like the Lotus Elise and the Caterham. With that they come with their own realistic sound effects which again helps boost immersion.So all in all - it's great. Despite the technical problems it's had, I consider it one hell of a racing game. I find racing in this way more intense than the likes of Gran Turismo.Pros- Variety of quality content.- Truly immersive.- Car Customization a definite plus.Cons- Technical problems related to DRM- DRMRating: 8/10, despite technically issues.

												I got this game in hopes that it would be something of a Forza for PC. The car selection looked good, the track selection was not terrible but sadly, this is not really a product I can recommend, especially for those looking for a more serious, mature and functional experience.  1.) The intro video's are too loud, To the point where I had to go in the config files of the game to remove them so that they would not blow out my headphones every time I start the game. Minor annoyance but still worth noting.  2.) Very unstable. This game will crash when loading tracks, it will crash in the middle of races and there is very little that one can do about it. I had to actually reinstall the game entirely (verifying steam install did not help) to make a certain track even load without crashing.  3.) Really poor controls for the gamepad. This one took me by surprise, I would have thought that a game like Need for speed would be extremely controller friendly but sadly that is not the case. The cars feel floaty and unresponsive. There also seems to be some input lag that I can't really explain, it's a common issue that many complain about and for good reason (especially after enjoying the fantastic controls in F1 2013 and GTR2 on gamepad specifically).  4.) Unskippable intro videos to different race types during career. This is where the maturity falls through. When you select new race types, you are greeted with one of two (or three) "edgy" racing guys telling you how extreme they are and how much they love speed (and whatever else) while they describe the basics of the race type. I would not make a big deal of this but it is unskippable and their "personalities" are grating and immature at best. It's almost embarassing to watch.  5.) Rather silly race structure. Like other NFS games, you can't do a qualifying lap, you just start the race in whatever grid position that the game randomly puts you in. This is frustrating because you are usually faster than the AI (more about the AI next) and not having any means to compete for a grid position takes away control that you should really have.  6.) The AI is pretty awful. When you play a game like F1 2013 (or any other semi-realistic racing game), you will find that the AI is usually pretty conservative about risks, they won't crash into you too much and they won't try run you off the road. In this game however, the AI is really not out to win as much as it is out to make sure they crash into you and with the handling and physics the way it is, almost every collision (no matter how minor) will result in you spinning off the track or into a wall. This may not seem like a huge deal, you may say "get good" but you will understand once you see just how needlessly aggressive they are.  I don't often like to trash games and write negative reviews, I usually try to find the silver lining in any product that I purchase and while there are moments that I really do enjoy this game, it's overall quality leaves a lot to be desired and I will certainly not buy another NFS game in the future.

[Pros and cons summarised at end]As a huge racing fan, buying almost every game that releases I have to say that SHIFT 2 is among the best of them across the board.Unfortunately, it's Steam page is marred by reviews that start with 'excellent game' before proceeding to not recommend due to the DRM policies and performance issues in the Steam client (This was the last game Electronic Arts released on Steam before Origin came along). I, running a mid-range PC on an i5 and a R9 270 with 12GB RAM, have not noticed these issues so far, the main one being crashes to desktop, rendering unplayable unless placed in Origin (Which can supposedly be achieved with a copy/paste of the CD Key you receive). The second issue people see with this is its DRM policy, the game can only be installed on 5 PC's/across 5 system resets before it can be activated no more. If you are someone who intends to reset or purchase a new PC an additional 4 times whilst playing this game, this could be an issue, mind you EA Support is surprisingly good, last time I had issues installing a game they fixed it and gave me a limited edition upgrade on two occasions, but of course they will migrate you to Origin. When (and if according to these reviews) you get into the game, it is superb. The visuals still hold up incredibly well and the soundtrack within the menus and loading screens is great - composed with the assistance of award-winning composers, one of whom is now doing the Game of Thrones' soundtrack. The gameplay is immensely intense; you know if you hit the driver in front or brake slightly too late it could all be over in a savage first person crash. At most times this game is more of a survival horror than a racing game, it doesn't feature a rewind feature like most sim-racers of the time and instead of casing you as the car, you are actually cast as the driver, something racing games have never really tapped into. This is achieved by the amazing 'helmet cam', taking you not only into 1st person but direct from the driver’s vision. The cockpit blurs under high intensity, the camera shake is perfect and the tilt as you approach a corner really adds the dynamics and intensity, this is also aided by 'motivational' comms messages at the start of races and Vaughn Gittin Jr. who teaches you the basics and introduces you to events, his spotlight of which is drifting, which I have to say is pretty uncontrollable, the general consensus is that the drift events in the career are near impossible. The career overall is very good, you start low end in 'Modern D', D class vehicles such as hatchbacks and work your way up to the FIA GT1 World championship, along the way you are given tasters of what's in store such as time trials or 'hot laps' in Bugatti's and Lambo's which occur about 20% through the game alongside difficult and exhilarating championships and invitationals which can earn you McLaren's and exclusive Team Need for Speed/Speedhunters tuned beasts. Overall the career isn’t the longest and you can probably have it done in under 40 hours, but despite this you still won't have anywhere near enough to buy all the cars which you can still work for through quick events, online and seasonal events.  The cars in this game are very detailed and each have fully rendered interiors *cough* Gran Turismo 5 *cough*, all of them, par a few which are already done up, offer livery choices, including the ability to fully create your own with 100's of stickers which can be placed anywhere on the car, rim options and incredibly open and detailed handling tuning, alongside performance upgrades and body kits for every vehicle. The vehicle range is very varied, especially taking into account that PC players receive the classic Legends and Speedhunters DLC's for free with additional cars and career events. Cars range from classic & retro to hatchback, sport, super, hyper, muscle and open-wheel alongside their respective race versions and tunes from all across the world.Tracks are also very detailed, but you hardly have the time to look at them when your hitting 200mph and there’s a corner 70yds away - the selection is quite large with almost all the major and quite a few minor tracks from around the world present alongside a few fictional ones too. Pros:Car customisationRacing intensity and sense of speed is off the chartsVehicle selectionFree DLC packs for PCTrack rangeVisuals still hold up very wellSoundtrackCareer ProgressionCons:Pro's only apply if you get the game and it worksEA's DRM policyDrift eventsCan get frustratingOverall I would 100% recommend this game, unless you plan on restoring your PC an additional 4 times. Drift events are completely avoidable in the career progression.

												+ Good-looking (if slightly older) title+ Good selection of cars, if not as exhaustive as Forza and GT.+ Fun career mode- Cheesy VO work by a racer in the career mode, with no option to turn him off.- Unskippable cutscenes instead of a tutorial.- Handling is customizable, but bad on every setting.I just stopped playing this game before writing this review, and unfortunately I can't recommend it due to the steering. It's unresponsive and clunky. What I mean by that is this: you'll be in the middle of a big spoon curve, or coming out of a tight turn, and you wanna stay on that good line by evening out your steering at a spot that sets you up to get where you're looking to be on the track. But the game gets in your way. No matter how lightly you tap the thumbstick, your car will steer heavily in that direction. This results in out-of-control fishtails if you're aggressive in trying to correct the issue, or a trip into the grass/gravel/wall if you try to let it even itself out. There's very rarely any middle ground, and when I did nail it, it felt like luck, like the binary steering system just so happened to have a "notch" that put me where I was trying to go. This is an issue regardless of stability control or braking assistance settings, as I tried it all four different ways.It's not as noticeable with less powerful cars, but the more powerful the ride, the more glaring this issue becomes. The AI doesn't seem to have this problem. About the only way to consistently avoid it is to hit the brakes, slow to a crawl, then creep around the curve, at which point the AI either blows by you or rear-ends you.Considering this is a game about the joy of driving cars, and the driving part of it is so flawed, save your money for something better. Even at $5, I regret my purchase.

But the game itself:Compared to its main rivals at the time, Forza Motorsports 4 and Gran Turismo 5, Need for Speed: Shift 2 Unleashed offers an immersive Sim-cade racing experience that improves on its predecessor. NOTE: I used a controller. The AI seem to have very little spatial awareness and crashed into me often. Car selection is minimal compared to FM4 and GT5, but customization is equivalent to FM4. Upgrading, tuning, and vinyls are available in the game. Track selection is great! From real to fiction tracks, racing was varied and never got dull.Overall: It's a enjoyable sim-cade racer, but you might as well play Forza or Gran Turismo. They just have more content and adept. 												First off, don't be fooled by my low amount of hours here on Steam with this game, I have done 2 playthough's when I owned it on the Xbox360.This is a really good racing game that sits between not a full on arcade racer, but also not a full on sim racer. For me, it is a good balance between the two. I absolutely loved the first Shift and eagerly awaited this sequel. IMO, it did a good job of expanding and improving the many greats about the first one, while still managing to up the ante and introduce some new things. One of the biggest improvements individuals will notice after playing the first one is the way you upgrade the performance of the vehicles. If you've played Forza 3/4, then this type is oh so familiar to you. There is now a much wider range of performance options instead of the tried and true Tier 1, 2, 3 formats. In this you are granted with pretty much any aspect of the car you could think of upgrading and giving them all to you off the bat, the strategy is finding that sweet spot balance of parts to give you the edge, without going over the performance rank (A, B, C, D etc.), which is what races are locked to, or going over your budget.The physics are neither the best, nor as detailed as games like Forza or GT, but the damage and handling models are pretty stellar IMO. As I said previously this is not a full blown Simulation racer. This game is pretty deep as far as modern racers go these days so that’s good and I expect the average person to get a good solid 30+ hours out of just the single player career alone.The AI in this game is quite comical sometimes and makes for some random comical relief. I normally play all my racing games in the highest of difficulty and even on "Hard" you will sometimes not too uncommonly see an AI opponent going full throttle in a straightaway and not even brake for the oncoming turn, leaving him careening off the track and slamming into the wall at high speeds leaving an explosion of parts and glass flying everywhere, or slamming into you or another AI opponents read end at full throttle, causing them (or you) to make like a space shuttle into the barricade. Sometime's I think they program to AI to do such nonsense to show off the physics engine haha!However, this is nowhere near a perfect racer by any means and comes with its laundry list of faults that is for sure. Some of the most annoying are: The randomly crazy handling, grazing another driver often leaves you defying the laws of physics, by careening you off the map or putting you into an uncontrollable spin even tapping an opponent in the right spot at relatively slow speeds and at times wired input lag. This also happens just grazing a wall or similar object, which will leaving you scratching your head at how just barely scraping the wall at 40 MPH, sends you into a uncontrollable 1080 degree(3 rotations) spin...Aside from that, the drifting in this game is absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ no thanks to some of the issues mentioned above and thankfully you can just skip that portion of the game entirely, other than the tutorial you are forced to do. Shift 2 still suffers from the dumbed down money system where after a few levels you have more money then you know what to do with and can max out every car you buy with ease, this kills some of the "I worked for this" feeling, or struggling to get that next little upgrade to give you more of an edge. Shift 2 no longer has that "Obviously best car in the class" problem that was in the first Shift where there was that one car that was leaps and bounds better than the rest of the cars in that class as far as performance went. With the addition of a horde of new cars, quantity of cars and classes and the Performance Index system, there is now a whole new level of strategy in picking and choosing the best cars and parts to suit your gameplay, while still staying in the Performance Index rating.In the end this is a decent console port with everything else being truly satisfying. Good deep racing scene with multiple disciplines, sometimes seemingly endless amounts of races, character leveling system, good customization esp. for performance parts and The graphics which I know most put a lot of emphasis on are decent, not as good as say Grid 2 etc., but still good eye candy in Ultra settings. 8/10

												This is a tough game to properlly review, so please take the thumbs up with a grain of salt at the moment. On its own, the game has a host of unique features and problems as compared to its competitors (especially of those on the consoles.) Then compared to the original Shift game, it also made some improvements but cut where it shouldn't have.But let's start with the basics. This is a simulator racing game. Or at least, that is what it is classified as. If you are wanting an open world experience with pursuits, save yourself the heartache and look at just about any other Need for Speed title because this game has none of that. This is a game that tries to create professional races with opponents that are about evenly matched with you as possible.So how does it do to that? Well, again, it comes in with a mixed bag. No, I can't honestly say that this is the most accurate game possible, but it isn't going to let you off with bad driving. In true Need for Speed fashion, the car list feels rather small and this time around we have a lot of repeating cars. Customization is a bit hit or miss as while we finally have engine swapping with the more specific engine parts to upgrade (not to the point of realism though,) there is still a linear upgrade in body kits and the vinyl designing seems to be even worse. At the very least, all cars can be upgraded with Works. Thankfully, tuning can be either simplified or extremely technical while also allow saving different settings for a given car for each track. Yep, you can have a special setting for the short, technical track and a different one for those at higher speeds and the game will automatically switch out based off the track and layout.The gameplay is where the game begins to shine over others though. Traffic is actually a thing as smashing your way through opponents is a bad idea over trying to (almost) safely weave through them. Night racing is absolutely wonderful and I have yet to find another racing game that tops it as while well lit tracks don't bring much issue, unlit tracks like the Nürburgring become a lot more difficult (and almost scary) to drive with not always being able to see around the corner. AI can also be fairly aggressive but not to the point of cheating or actually being unsportsman. If you play with the camera on dask or on helmet, the race feels more intense as it bobbles around like you are in the car itself, making even a quick run around a track by yourself in a low end car feel more intense than others with AI drivers with high end vehicles.The helmet cam is also a new feature to this game (that will probably leave due to things like the occulus rift.) The camera will look into the turn like a professional driver. While it takes some getting use to at first, it is well executed and does end up becoming quite helpful especially in larger vehicles but probably not needed for triple monitors.All of that said, Shift 2 is a fairly good place for people to try and break into the simulator genre. The game has a level system based on what you do and mini-achievments per race, meaning that just because you have a hard time winning doesn't mean you can't progress to the end. While different from the previous Shift title, it still does the job well at letting new players still get a chance to eventually move on but without being a hinderance to veterans of the genre.Now, how about against the original Shift? Well, more improvements and new issues. Yes, night time racing is a wonderful feature, helmet camera is appreciated, and the improved graphics are wonderful. But they have removed the unnamed crew chief who started the race for you with a real world professional driver. And yes, you will know that the new person helping you is a professional driver. And yes, it becomes a nusiance. No, Shift 2's new guy doesn't have an annoying voice but that it feels like he is lecturing you for every single race instead of seeming like you are part of the same team. We go from a grassroot driver becoming a legend to a grassroot driver who is forever in the shadow of his teacher. And then they brought in the rest of the real world drivers. Yep, every boss race is you against a real world racer betting their car against you. No weakness and they are not that interesting especially when almost all of them are driving a car sponsored by EA. I get that they might be trying to create buzz for the drivers, but this isn't a good way to get me excited for them.Allow me to wrap this up. Wanting a typical Need for Speed game? I recommend Hot Pursuit by Criterion. Want a super realistic simulator? Might be worth your time. Just want a fun yet fairly challenging racing game? This is probably up your alley. Looking for the proper sequel to Shift? Prepare for disappointments and be pleasantly surprised at certain points.

												Shift 2: Unleashed is as good as Need for Speed: Shift was bad. Bold statement as Shift 1 was widely praised for splitting the franchise and moving into the racing sim genre, breaking away from Need for Speed’s arcade roots. But it wasn’t quite there. Shift 1 was a prototype for the formula, testing what worked and what didn’t. What definitely didn’t work were the physics and handling. Floaty, unresponsive and still clinging to the series traits. An EA inclusion more than Slightly Mad Studios, as the UK developers were definitely capable of more precise and realistic handling based on their earlier GTR games. However, the cockpit view was an absolute blessing and Shift 2: Unleashed drastically improves the handling to match the visually stunning cockpit view.GameplayShift 2’s cockpit view is the best and most visceral experience I’ve ever seen in a racing game. Not only is it highly accurate and detailed, the cockpit also features amazing effects. Wing mirrors shake at high speeds, vision is blurred at those speeds, the dashboard is reflected on the windscreen, shifting, handbrake and pedal actions are all intricately animated, dirt flicks on to the windscreen, rubber and gravel ‘marbles’ hit the undercarriage and wheel arches and high speed crashes cause violent shaking, temporary loss of vision and heavy breathing from the driver. Also the option to have a helmet camera further emphasises the impact as well as the precision as the head sways towards the corner direction for added realism. The third person camera offers the chance to view the detailed cars from behind but it doesn’t offer the connection the player has with the car as the camera is a bit too floaty, I like that word, making it hard to aim for the apexes. Luckily, the improvements in handling have made it much easier to point a car at an apex. Turning off all assists, except ABS and Automatic (c’mon now), produces the most rewarding driving experience in a racing game. Throttle control is vital as well as judging the braking zone and corner angle all to get the best exit creating intense racing. Immersion can be broken however by the slightly over-aggressive AI drivers who have no problem PIT manoeuvring you off the track or blocking you on straights. A little more Jenson and little less Pastor would’ve made a less frustrating battle for 1st. This is tied to the fact that Unleashed doesn’t have a rewind feature made popular by Codemasters and now prominent in the Forza series. Thank God though, as racing intensifies in the latter stages making it a white knuckle ride to the finish line without a safety net.Career progression is improved above and beyond Shift 1’s silly star system as well as the XP rewards being based on good driving rather than awarding careless racing. Videos by real-life racers and drifters such as Vaughn Gittin Jr. introduce each racing category and you are provided the opportunity to learn and hone the skills before heading out on track. Need for Speed fans are also given extra cash and cars for their dedication to the franchise, which helps save up cash to buy their dream cars. Unlike Shift 1, to race a car in Hot Lap mode, you have to buy the car in career mode. Perhaps unfair, but it gives a real incentive to finish gold in every race and manage the cash in order to afford the cars you really want. Helpfully, cars can be sold for the price bought making it easy to sell the lower-powered sports cars necessary for a category in order to save for a hypercar. The car list is smaller than GT5 or Forza 4, but it ignores the unnecessary hatchbacks and endless Nissans of the GT series. The cars here are focussed racing machines and monstrous production cars all with beautifully detailed interiors and exteriors with moving airbrakes and wings. Not included are any Ferraris but the Porsche selection more than makes up for it. The diverse variety of tracks features all the greats such as Suzaka, Silverstone and Spa as well as an interpretation of the Monaco GP circuit. TechnicalThe sounds are loud. My headphone volume was at 50% most of the time and sometimes lower at night. The cars sound great though and the noticeable differences in sound from the cockpit view to behind the exhaust demonstrate the attention to detail that Slightly Mad paid. The graphics are impressive not just the cars but also the track surroundings, including helicopters and planes flying over whilst racing. Night racing is also a welcome addition with tactics having to alter and slight apprehensiveness when approaching blind bends. The ability to turn off HUD whilst in-game is also a brilliant addition as you can have the lap times and positions when you need them and turn them off to not obscure the view without breaking the flow of the race.  The framerate could be improved though as modding was the only way to uncap the 30fps limit.VerdictTurn off assists. Stick it in cockpit view and go RACE.90%

Posted: January 12, 2015
												As far as I'm concerned, this is a very poorly done console port. The keyboard keys are bound to impossible keys, in game mechanics aren't optimized to PC, and the AI is poorly done, not to mention the fact that the game crashes often on high graphics.Before diving into issues, i want to dive into a major issue with this game: The long, unskippable in-game movies that can't decide which volume they want to be. For starters there's the intro movie, that gets incredibly loud, and is only skippable after all the logo's displayed. These don't read into your personal volume preferences though, and are extremely loud, which is especially annoying when you play with a headset. Then, there's introduction videos that introduce you into a certain "event". These can be cool, but you need to be able to skip them. If you're hyped up for a race beforehand, a 2 minute long movie can only get you out of that hype. The fact that you actually have to delete the movies out of your data map, is a ridiculous thing in it's own. Now that that's out of the way, on to my major flaws with this game.My first issue with this game is the horrible standard controls that the game asks you to use. This would be with the arrow keys, and the insert / delete button to shift gears. And yes, you use the up arrow for throttle. A controller of sorts makes the game easier to handle, even though this also isn't perfect. You can control in-game fully with a controller, but as soon as you enter any menu, including the pause menu, you are forced to use the keyboard. Especially when in-game this is a very poor point, given that you have to sit ready with your controller already in your hand, before pressing either the enter or escape button on your keyboard.My second problem lays in the fact that a lot of the in game mechanics aren't optomized for pc. Left and right scrolling through the main menu goes with the arrow keys, while sub menu's always go with either U and I, or J and K, depending on what you want to do. The customization mechanic is sensitive beyond believe, and isn't, like most of the game, controllable with a controller, making it virtually impossible to line stickers up. Most of the engine / steering upgrades are standard, and it is clear that EA has it's favorite cars that are being favored. Some of the works cars (which are supposed to be the maxed out performance cars) are so horrible, that it's impossible to control on a circuit. Finally, the poor AI. I find myself having to reset the track about 15 to 20 times, especially at the beginning,  to be even able to race in a fair matter. More often then wished, i find way too many cars bumping in on me, and spinning me out of control, making it impossible to even have a fair chance at winning. When I instead try to do the same, the cars seem to be magnetized to the track, and are unable to even get off. It's like bumping into an almost static object, sending you spinning, or even flipping out of control, but AI driven cars are completely fine. The most that the AI will do for you, is try and steer about half a meter clear from you, so that you can try and clear a corner. But more often then not, they still bump into your back and send you spinning. That being said, I don't think the game is entirely just bad things. There are some positives, the cars generally look awesome, and there is some fun to be had in multiplayer, or attempting to break the AI in a race. If you are successful, it's definitely worth the effort, and you could get some laughs out of that. I wouldn't say the game is worth the full 20 euro's that are currently charged, but wait until it's on sale sometime. 5 Euro's is about what the game is worth, in my opinion.

												The second and probably last Shift game to come by Slightly Mad Studios.It is very similar to Shift but also very different.Graphics/PerformanceThe graphics on Shift where great for a 2009 game and the same follows for Shift 2. They are similar but slightly better compared to Shift especially on the vinyle quallity. The surroundings on the track are not the greatest but it is hard to notice when you are gunning it down the track at 180 MPH. The car detail is very nice and the paints look very pretty. For me at least the game runs fine but every once in a while when starting a race it gets ♥♥♥♥ing slow for a few moments and goes back to normal. Other than that it performs great on my PC. I'd give it a 9/10 on graphics/performance for a game from 2011.GameplayWell for one the gameplay is totally different from Shift. They took the realisim up a notch on the way cars feel and handle compared to Shift. Drifting has also been made way different compared to Shift and is actually quite hard for most people. Overall the game is probably 2 times as hard as Shift was. The customizing like in Shift sucks just the same with no paintable wheels and hardly any vinyles to apply thus making it impossible to make your own liveries. This makes me feel forced to use the pre made liveries that look bad IMHO which leads me to just paint my cars metallic blue and be done with it. The vinyling system was definatly improved since Shift but they removed a great number of vinyles and made 90% of them only one colour. The AI can be annoying at times especially on small, tight tracks as they will push you out of their way in a hairpin making it almost impossible to win. I'd give gameplay a 8/10 only because of the crappy vinyling system.OverallOverall this game is fun and challenging making it very entertaining for me. Nothing beats blasting around the Nordschleife in a 1986 Toyota Corolla AE86 with over 800 HP. If you like racing simulators, buy it. If you like cars, buy it. If you like drifitng, buy it. If you want your Vette to handle like a Lotus and be fast, I'd run and never look back.

												Honestly the game is fun for maybe 15 minutes at a time. After that you remember that it is another EA floater that someone forgot to flush down the toilet.PROSGreat visuals (tracks, cars, and even cockpit interiors all look good)Very customizable cars with advanced tuning features brought back from some older NFS titlesVehicle damage is great and somewhat realistic (but sadly no total carnage from a serious crash)CONSThe "pep talks" from Vaughn Gittin before and after the races make me want to jam a sharp instrument into each of my ears. I appreciate that he's a drift champion, but listening to his drole, useless commentary over and over makes me wish he was never born.There is a significant and noticable delay in the handling for all the controllers and wheels that I tested with this game. You basically have to turn early to compensate for this painful delay or you will end up in a wall on every corner.The interface, like so many other EA titles, is a Frankenstein's monster patchwork glued together from console versions. As a result, the menu navigations are nonsensical and tedious. As an example of this: you cannot adjust controls and sensitivities during a paused race; instead you must exit the race, go all the way back to the first menu, change the controls, then start the race over again.The EA autolog is forced down your throat and completely useless. It slows down load times and will often cause the game to hang indefinitely during a track load if you do not block it with a firewall.The AI, if you can even call it that, will often mistake the race track for a demolition derby. They will slam into you when you slow for corners, clip your tail and spin you out, and all sorts of other shennanigans unrelated to racing and with no fear of disqualification. Likewise, you can slam into them and generally wreak havoc without any fear of disqualification, so go nuts! My favorite is when two AI side-swipe each other in the first corner and then slow to a stop as they both try to turn into one another.The intro sequence for each race always seems to have frame stutter and audio clipping regardless of video detail settings. But then the races go by without any frame issues on high details.

												Shift 2 Unleashed was a solid racing game and the first one I've played to completion on career mode of 100%.  While I would recommend this game, I do so with some caveats, which I will list in the cons.  The most important point people need to know is that controls have to be customized heavily, I used an Xbox 360 controller for windows and the stock settings were awful, however I followed some guides online and tweaked a couple ini files and was good to go.  Here is the guide that was helpful for me setting up controls: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2270539Pros: - Lots of races- Good variety of cars- Most cars look great and have great interiors- AI makes mistakes on occasion, even knocking themselves out of the race- AI will bump into you more if you start driving dirty- Difficulty Levels and driving assists really let you tailor this into either a sim racer or arcade, I like it closer to sim but not all the way there and played with no damage, driving assist line, medium AI, elite handling mode and all driving assists turned off.Cons:- Crashes (not the kind you'd expect, in my 75+ hours I've probably had about 30 crashes to desktop, sometimes losing progress, particularly maddening on endurance races).- Ignored/Lost progress bug.  I noticed this when doing the last drag races, often times the race results screen would show up twice and I would lose all my progress and have to repeat the series, very annoying but after 3 tries on each of the last standing mile races I was able to get through.- Challenges like the modern A invitational can be difficult because you are provided with a car and not able to tune it for the track (makes for a frustrating experience at times).- "Cut the track" bugs.  Perhaps I'm misinformed but on a few tracks if you go too wide on a turn (understeer) into the grass and then come back to the same turn it would say "you've cut the track!".  I call BS on that, I thought cutting the track was when you took a shortcut through a turn on the inside grass, not the outside.  This was infuriating on one particular track where following the ideal race line would put you into this situation on purpose, even with just two wheels off.- Other general bugs, none of the "videos" unlocked even though I completed the career stuff for them.- Not enough levels, Max level in game is 20, after that you keep earning experience but it goes nowhere.  I hit level 20 by 45% career completion.  Why build levels in at all when they end that soon?All in all, this was a fun experience and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a racer that helps bridge the gap between simulation and arcade.  8 / 10

Posted: October 13, 2014
												I had high expectations for this game.A notorious series for it's fun, unrealistic racing games moving into more simulated racing experience? It sounds like it could have potential to me, but then I bought it and I, a fan of racing games of this genre, hated it.Don't get me wrong, the graphics are top-notch and the scenario of the game is also brilliant; something that many games of the same genre lack and need overall in my opinion, but the game itself - physically - irritated me.There is an imput lag within the hame, and whilst it is only small, overall, it affects a racing game moreso than most. The time that it took for the responses to take action ruined the whole experience, as I was unable to make corners in time or brake at the exact right distance from the corner, whereas in other games it would have been alright. A higher powered PC than mine might be able to handle it, however, the problem seems to affect a large amount of the audience that play the game.The physics also annoy me. They are so light, it is almost like someone has attatched a group of helium baloons to the cars as so they float. This would be okay, I guess if not for the juiced-up, ROID RAGING, AI drivers, of whose sole purpose is to shove you off the track. Some may see this a being "Fun" and "Well Programmed", however, I can see that the opposite cars are meant to follow a ceirtain track and do not adjust that as so to avoid you down straights and corners, making them hit you if you go inside of the corner fairly - I'm not talking about rusing into the corner as so the others hit you, but coming into the corner in line with another racer, of whom shoves you out of line for no absolute reason other than for them trying to follow a direct path through the corner, of which is interrupted. Bad coding is the reason for this, I would presume.Finally, the last thing that annoys me is the modes. They would be fine in any other game, but in this game speciffically, they do not work. Drifting is the equivalent of spinning out until a path is found, of which you repeat for a while before the game notices and gives you an amount of points equivalent to a small amount of drift, as the mechanics of picking up on drifts are basically broken beyond belief. The races, coupled with bad AI and physics are unbearible and the drag events... well, they were ok, actually, you dont turn, just drive in a straight line. If only there were more than three of them.Overall, this game is bad in my opinion, but strangely infatuating to return to, even though you know you will have a bad time. Why I have been on it for 17.5 hours is beyond me. I would not get this If I were looking for a racing game at all. I would instead resort to the internet looking for sim racers. I found a good Free to Play one recently called SimRaceWay, of which is worth a look, it is much better than this game to many a regard.

												Recommend a steering wheel but it's playable with a gamepad (cannot recommend kb).the gameplay is exciting and there's a unique thril of speed in the cockpit mode.as any racing game the game starts you off in relatively normal every day cars but quite quickly expands in to interesting car terretory, once you start tuning you will find out that you can be faster with the assists off and some select tuning, but the driving will become very challanging if you just tune for power (a wheel makes it easier since you have more controll).with assists it can pass as a pc version of forza, higher fidelity less cars.without assits and a wheel it's a fantastic experience if your in to racing games.a perfect balance between arcade and sim.note :there is a issue with the launcher, steam versions cannot play well with origin / disked versions (cars warping all over the place).the fix is... in a gray legal zone so how to obtain it i will leave up to you.if you use a disk version of shift 2 to launch the game without installing it (just having it installed in steam) the game will launch with no online issue's.it works fine with other steam versions out the box though.
